tn.text: The former book I wrote - The former book is the Gospel of Luke.

O Theophilus - Luke wrote this book to a man named Theophilus. The word “O” is used because Luke was addressing him. Some translations follow their own culture's way of addressing a letter and write "Dear Theophilus" at the beginning of the sentence. Theophilus means "friend of God." (See: [[:en:ta:translate:translatenames]])

tn.ref: until the day that he was received up
tn.text: until the day that he was received up - This refers to Jesus' ascension into heaven.
command through the Holy Spirit - The Holy Spirit lead Jesus to instruct his apostles on certain things.
after his suffering - This refers to Jesus' suffering and death on the cross.
appearing to many others - Jesus appeared to many of his disciples beyond the original 12 apostles.
When he… - "he" is referring to Jesus.
with them… - "them" is referring to the 11 apostles.

tn.ref: he commanded them not to leave Jerusalem
tn.text: he commanded them not to leave Jerusalem - "he ordered them to remain in Jerusalem". This can also be translated with a direct quote as in the UDB. (See: [[en:ta:vocabulary:quotation]])
promise of the Father - This is a reference to the Holy Spirit.

tn.ref: baptized with water…baptized in the Spirit
tn.text: baptized with water…baptized in the Spirit - Jesus contrasted John's baptism with water, to God's baptism which will be with the Holy Spirit.

For languages that require an object with "baptize,"  this can be translated as "John baptized people with water" or "John baptized them with water." (See: Verbs and Objects in [[en:ta:vocabulary:verbs]])\\
This can be translated with an active verb: "God will baptize you." (See: [[en:ta:vocabulary:active]])
times or seasons - "times or dates".
you will receive power - "you will be spiritually strengthened."
This is the result of receiving power. This can also be translated as "to be my witnesses" to show that this was the purpose of the power.

tn.ref: to the ends of the earth
tn.text: to the ends of the earth - “all over the world” or “even to the far away places on the earth”.
as they were looking up - "as the apostles were looking up at the sky"

tn.ref: he vanished into a cloud out of their sight
tn.text: "He went up into the sky, and a cloud blocked their view of him and they could not see Him anymore."
looking intensely to heaven - "staring at the sky" or "gazing at the sky"
Specifically "you apostles". Though the angels spoke to the apostles, other verses suggest that other disciples, both men and women,  were present at this event.

tn.ref: why do you stand looking into heaven?
tn.text: why do you stand looking into heaven? - This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement as in the UDB. (See: [[:en:ta:figuresofspeech:rhetoricalquestion]])
Then they returned - "the apostles returned"
a sabbath day's journey - A rule the Pharasees made to keep people from doing work on the sabbath.
When they arrived - "When they reached their destination in Jerusalem"
upper chamber - a room on a higher level of the house.
"Simon the Patriot." There were many Zealots. But Simon may have been the only apostle who was a Zealot. The Zealots wanted to make the Romans stop ruling over Israel.

tn.ref: They were all united as one
tn.text: They were all united as one - The group was united and did not have divisions or strife.

tn.ref: as they diligently continued in prayer
tn.text: "as they devoted themselves together to pray"
In those days - "In those days shortly after Jesus went back to heaven"

tn.ref: in the midst of the brothers
tn.text: "brothers" often refers to fellow believers and would include both men and women.

tn.ref: It was necessary that the scripture should be fulfilled
tn.text: It was necessary that the scripture should be fulfilled - Peter is specifically addressing the prophecies that related to Judas.
"the words of David." The word "mouth" is used to refer to "words" even though David wrote them. (See: [[en:ta:figuresofspeech:metonymy]])
"his evil act of guiding Jesus' enemies to him." This makes explicit what "evil act" refers to. (See [[en:ta:vocabulary:implicitexplicit]])

tn.ref: Then falling head first his body burst wide open and all his bowels poured out.
tn.text: <b>Then falling head first his body burst wide open and all his bowels poured out.<b>  - On this plot of land, Judas had a severe head first fall that caused his body to burst open. Other scriptures mention he hung himself.

tn.ref: It became known...the field of blood.
tn.text: <b>It became known...the field of blood.<b>  -  Because of the death, the people started calling the field by a new name.

tn.ref: For it is written in the book of Psalms
tn.text: For it is written in the book of Psalms - Based on the situation with Judas that he just recounted, Peter is recalling a passage in the book of Psalms that he believes relates to the current situation.
the book of Psalms - This can be translated as "the book of Hymns" or "the book of Songs." This book is part of the scriptures.

tn.ref: Let his field be made desolate
tn.text: Let his field be made desolate - A property falling apart and overgrown suggests the owner is dead.

tn.ref: And do not let even one person live there
tn.text: the land is unclean (taboo) or is unfit to live on.

tn.ref: let someone else take his position of leadership
tn.text: let someone else take his position of leadership - "may he be replaced in his leadership position"
Peter is about to express why he quoted the verses from Psalms and what they should do about it.

tn.ref: That the men who accompanied us ...one of these must be a witness with us of his resurrection
tn.text: That the men who accompanied us ...one of these must be a witness with us of his resurrection - Peter defined the qualifications for the man who is to replace Judas as an apostle.
They put forward two men - As they looked to replace Judas, they found two men who qualified.

tn.ref: Joseph called Barsabbas who was also named Justus
tn.text: Joseph was also known by the names Barsabbas and Justus.
godly men - people who wanted to honor and or worship God
every nation under heaven - "every nation in the world"

when this sound was heard - This refers to the sound that was like a strong wind. This can be translated with an active verb: "when they heard this sound." (See: [[:en:ta:vocabulary:active|Active or Passive]])
the multitude - "the large crowd of people"
Galileans - This can be translated as "from Galilee."

tn.ref: Why is it that we are hearing them
tn.text: Why is it that we are hearing them - This could be 1) a real question that the people wanted an answer to, or 2) a rhetorical question that expressed how amazed they were. The UDB translates it as a statement showing how surprised they were. (See: [[:en:ta:figuresofspeech:rhetoricalquestion|Rhetorical Question]])
Parthians and Medes and Elamites - "people from Parthia, Media and Elam." (See: [[:en:ta:translate:translatenames|How to Translate Names]])
proselytes - "non-Jewish people who have become Jews" or "people who have changed their religion and become Jews" or "converts to the Jewish religion"
What does this mean? - Some took the event seriously.
But others mocked - "But others insulted" or "put down"

tn.ref: They are full of new wine
tn.text: They are full of new wine - This can be translated as "They are drunk." Some chose to not believe the miracle, but to mock the apostles.
new wine - a stronger drink than normal wine
All the apostles stood up in support of Peter's statement.

tn.ref: it is the third hour of the day
tn.text: "It is only nine o'clock in the morning" (UDB). Peter expected his audience to know that people don't get drunk that early in the day. It is implicit information that can be made explicit if needed. (See: [[en:ta:vocabulary:implicitexplicit]])

tn.ref: this is what was spoken through the prophet Joel
tn.text: "This is what God said and told the prophet Joel to write" or "The prophet Joel wrote these things that God had said."
This can be translated with an active verb: "what God said" or "what God spoke about." (See: [[en:ta:vocabulary:active]])

tn.ref: It will be in the last days
tn.text: This can be translated as "In the last days." The things that he is about to speak of will happen in the last days. This is the first part of what God said. The words "God says" can come first as in the UDB.

tn.ref: pour out Spirit upon all flesh
tn.text: pour out Spirit upon all flesh - This is a figure of speech telling how abundantly God will give his Spirit to all people.
"all people." The word "flesh" refers to people because people are made of flesh. (See: [[en:ta:figuresofspeech:synecdoche]])

tn.ref: I will pour out my Spirit
tn.text: God gives his Spirit generously.
God inspires them to speak God's truth
"mist" or "fog"
pour out -This is like someone emptying out a lot of water from a pitcher or a bucket. Translate this the same way you did on the last frame.

tn.ref: the sun will be turned to darkness and the moon to blood
tn.text: The exact meaning of this phrase is unclear, just translate it as literally as possible into your language.
prays or pleads
This is the plural form of your. If your language has a different word for you(plural) use it.
he was delivered up - "men delivered him", "you handed him over", "people delivered him"
loosed - untied like one unties a rope
<b>held <b>  - death could not finally keep Jesus in its power
I saw - David foresaw God working in his life before events unfolded
before my face - in my presence, with me
beside my right hand - the right hand was considered the strongest. Someone at the right hand was either the strongest servant, or strongest helper.

tn.ref: my heart was glad and my tongue rejoiced
tn.text: my heart was glad and my tongue rejoiced - outward expression was given of inward joy

tn.ref: my flesh shall dwell in hope
tn.text: my flesh shall dwell in hope - "I will hope in God as long as I live"
Your holy one - "Your anointed or chosen one".
To see decay - "To experience corruption" or "rot"
ways of life - "life-giving truth"
patriarch - father, one who lived a long time ago
<b>oath <b>  - a solemn statement or declaration
<b>swear an oath <b>  - to make a serious statement that what one promises is true
brothers - inclusive language for both men and women
<b>right hand of God <b>  - "a place of confidence, honor, favor, trust, reliance, power and privileges of God".

tn.ref: the Lord said to my Lord
tn.text: "the Lord (God) said to my Lord (Christ)"
"take your place of honor, trust, privileges and power", by my side

tn.ref: until I make your enemy a stool for your feet
tn.text: "until I put your enemy in a position or place of defeat for you"
separate yourselves
morally and spiritually crooked
believed, accepted
were baptized - Jesus' disciples baptized them
"shared all of their possessions"
gave them to or shared the proceeds with or gave money to
believed the same thing
when a need was expressed or observed, other believers gave to meet that need
with one purpose - "with one mind"
they continued - "the believers continued"
broke bread - shared a meal, shared the Lord's Supper (UDB).
humility of heart - without presumption, plainly, without unnecessary formality, without regard to rank or privilege
had favor with - had the respect of
into the temple - "into the temple area" or "to the temple." They did not go into the inner building which only the serving priests were allowed.
alms - "Alms" refers to money that people give to the poor. The man was poor and was asking for money for himself.
fastening his eyes upon him - "staring at him" or "looking intently at him"

tn.ref: the lame man looked at them
tn.text: the lame man looked at them - "the lame man paid close attention to them"

silver and gold - This is placed at the beginning of the sentence to show that this is what the man expects to receive but Peter does not have any, and to contrast it with what Peter does have and want to give him. The phrase "silver and gold" is a mentonym for money. (See: [[:en:ta:figuresofspeech:metonymy]])
He entered ... into the temple - This would be the temple courtyard. Only the priests were allowing to enter the actual temple building.
the Beautiful Gate - "the Gate called Beautiful"
noticed - "perceived" or "recognized" or "saw"
wonder and amazement -"greatly amazed" (UDB) or "surprised and astonished"
As - "While"

tn.ref: the porch that was called Solomon's
tn.text: the porch that was called Solomon's - "Solomon's Porch." Solomon was the name of a king of Israel who had lived long before that time. A porch is a row of pillars covered by a roof, and open on one side. This could be translated as "Solomon's Veranda." Solomon's Porch was very large.
<b>greatly marveling <b>  - "full of surprise" or "astonished" or "full of awe"
When Peter saw this - "When Peter saw the crowd growing" or "When Peter saw the people" (UDB)
You men of Israel - "Fellow Israelites" (UDB). Peter was addressing the crowd. "men" in this context would extend to everyone present (men, women, children).

tn.ref: Why do you marvel at this man
tn.text: Why do you marvel at this man - This is a rhetorical question. It can be translated as "you should not be surprised" UDB. (See: [[en:ta:figuresofspeech:rhetoricalquestion]])

tn.ref: Why do you fix your eyes on us
tn.text: Why do you fix your eyes on us - This rhetorical question can also be translated as "You should not focus on us" or "There is no reason for you to focus on us."
"us" refers to Peter and John, the dual & exclusive form.
"we" refers to Peter and John, the dual & exclusive form.

tn.ref: as if we had made him to walk by our own power or godliness?
tn.text: This is a rhetorical question. It can be translated as "We did not make him walk by our own power or godliness."
"whom  you brought to Pilate"

tn.ref: and denied before the face of Pilate
tn.text: "and you rejected him in Pilate's presence"

tn.ref: when he had decided to release him
tn.text: "when Pilate had decided to set Jesus free"

tn.ref: for a murderer to be released to you
tn.text: This can be translated with an active verb: "for Pilate to give a murderer to you."
to be released to you - "to be given to you." This means "to be given as a favor." It does not mean "to be freed" as from a trap.
Prince of life - "The author of life" (UDB) or "ruler of life"
has made this man strong - "has given this man complete health"
faith in his name - Languages that don't have a noun meaning "faith" might need to use a verb meaning believe or trust. If they need to tell who believed, they can specify "we".
captain of the temple - chief security guard of the temple
came upon them - "approached them" or "came to them"
They were deeply troubled - Peter taught about Jesus and his resurrection from the dead. This troubled the Sadducees because they did not believe in Jesus' resurrection from the dead.
the number of the men - specifically males. Any women and children who were there were not included in the count.
since it was now evening - It was common practice not to question people at night.
was about five thousand - "became about five thousand" or "grew to about five thousand".
"who gave you power" (UDB) or "what gave you power." They knew Peter and John could not have healed this man on their own.
"who gave you authority"
citizens of the nation Israel.
when they saw the boldness - "they" refers to the group leaders.
realized that they - "perceiving" or "knowing"
they were ordinary - "they" refers to two, Peter and John.
<b>knowing that Peter <b>  - "were recognizing that Peter"
"untrained" or "no formal schooling"
we cannot deny it - "we cannot deny the miracle". Everyone in Jerusalem already knows that the man was healed.
them - Refers to two, Peter and Paul.
"do not speak anymore"
we cannot help - we are compelled to speak
whether it is right - righteous and honoring to God

tn.ref: they were unable to find any excuse to punish them
tn.text: the leaders could not figure out how to punish Peter and John without causing a riot among the people who saw the man healed
the leaders threatened them with further punishment

tn.ref: The man…was more than forty years old
tn.text: it was a well established fact that he was a cripple and was recently healed.
imagine useless things - unprofitable things; unrealistic things
set themselves together - they came together. They joined their armies together.

tn.ref: Herod and Pontius Pilate, together with the Gentiles and the people of Israel
tn.text: Herod and Pontius Pilate, together with the Gentiles and the people of Israel - David included only the Gentile nations, but Peter included Israel and their rulers as those who opposed the Messiah.
in this city - in Jerusalem

tn.ref: they spoke the word of God with boldness
tn.text: this is result of the disciples being filled with the Holy Spirit.

tn.ref: The great number of those who believed...
tn.text: <b>The great number of those who believed...<b>  - "Many people who believed..."
sold…brought the money…distribution was made - Various believers did this over time, not all at once.

tn.ref: laid it at the apostles’ feet
tn.text: It was the believers way to express: 1) publicly demonstrate a changed heart, and 2) giving the apostles the authority over the distribution of the gift.
It seems the needs of believers were observed over a period of time; items were not simply handed out whenever someone said they needed something.

tn.ref: Joseph, a Levite, a man from Cyprus
tn.text: Barnabas is being introduced into the story. It isn't until later that he has a bigger part in Luke's book of Acts. you may need to consider how your language introduces new participants in a story.

tn.ref: laid it at the apostles’ feet
tn.text: This was the common way for believers to give and it symbolizes giving the apostles the authority over the use of the gift.
